What's the exact order of stations in a Hyrox race? I keep seeing different lists online.

There's only one order and it never changes — every Hyrox race worldwide follows the exact same sequence. Here it is:

1. **Run 1 (1 km)** → **SkiErg** (1,000 m)
2. **Run 2 (1 km)** → **Sled Push** (50 m — 4 x 12.5 m lengths)
3. **Run 3 (1 km)** → **Sled Pull** (50 m — 4 x 12.5 m lengths)
4. **Run 4 (1 km)** → **Burpee Broad Jumps** (80 m)
5. **Run 5 (1 km)** → **Rowing** (1,000 m)
6. **Run 6 (1 km)** → **Farmers Carry** (200 m)
7. **Run 7 (1 km)** → **Sandbag Lunges** (100 m)
8. **Run 8 (1 km)** → **Wall Balls** (100 reps)

That's **8 x 1 km runs** alternating with **8 functional stations** — 8 km of running total, same for every division. The only things that change between divisions are the **weights** at the stations.

**Why this matters for your training:** The order is deliberate. The sled push and sled pull are back-to-back (Stations 2 and 3), which absolutely destroys your legs before you even hit burpee broad jumps. And wall balls come dead last when you're most fatigued. Your training needs to simulate this sequencing — don't just train stations in isolation. Practice the *transitions* between them, especially sled push → Run 3 → sled pull and sandbag lunges → Run 8 → wall balls.

What are the weights for Men's Open division? I want to make sure I'm training with the right loads.

Good — training with race weights is non-negotiable. Here are the **exact Men's Open weights** from the official 2025/26 HYROX rulebook:

|---------|---------------|
| **SkiErg** | 1,000 m (no weight) |
| **Sled Push** | **152 kg** total (includes sled — about 100 kg added to the ~52 kg sled) |
| **Sled Pull** | **103 kg** total (includes sled — about 50 kg added) |

**Key detail:** Men's Open weights are identical to Women's Pro weights. The only difference is the wall ball target height — Men's Open throws to 3.00 m (10 ft), Women's Pro throws to 2.70 m (9 ft).

**Training application:** Get a 152 kg sled push and 103 kg sled pull dialed into your weekly training ASAP. If your gym sled is different from the race sled (~52 kg base), do the math and load accordingly. Train wall balls at 6 kg to a 10-foot target — no exceptions. Using a lighter ball or lower target in training will bite you on race day.

What's the difference between Men's Pro and Men's Open weights?

Big differences. This is why division choice matters so much. Here's the full comparison:

| Station | Men's Open | Men's Pro |
|---------|------------|----------|
| **Sled Push** | 152 kg (incl. sled) | **202 kg** (incl. sled) — that's 50 kg heavier |
| **Sled Pull** | 103 kg (incl. sled) | **153 kg** (incl. sled) — also 50 kg heavier |
| **Farmers Carry** | 2 x 24 kg (grey) | **2 x 32 kg** (black) — 16 kg more total |
| **Sandbag Lunges** | 20 kg (grey) | **30 kg** (black) — 50% heavier |
| **Wall Balls** | 6 kg to 3.00 m | **9 kg / 20 lbs** to 3.00 m — 50% heavier ball |

SkiErg, rowing, and burpee broad jumps are **identical** across both divisions.

**Why this matters:** The Pro sled push at 202 kg is a beast — that's roughly a 150 kg load you're pushing on top of the sled. The 9 kg wall ball to a 10-foot target for 100 reps at the end of the race is where Pro division truly separates from Open. You need serious strength-endurance to handle those loads when fatigued.

**My recommendation:** If this is your first or second Hyrox, race Open. The 50 kg difference on sleds alone can mean 2-3 extra minutes per station if you're not prepared. Master the Open weights first, then make the jump to Pro when you can complete a full simulation at Pro weights without your station times ballooning more than 15-20% above your Open times.

**Important note for Worlds:** If you qualify for the World Championships in an age group under 60, you race at **Pro weights regardless** of whether you qualified in Open.

How much of the race is actually running vs doing stations?

This is one of the most important things to understand about Hyrox, and most people get it wrong. Here's the data:

A peer-reviewed study by Brandt et al. (2025) published in *Frontiers in Physiology* found that for recreational athletes (median finish ~86.5 min):

- **Running: ~59% of total race time** (median 51.2 minutes)
- **Stations: ~38% of total race time** (median 32.8 minutes)
- **Roxzone/Transitions: ~3-7%** of total race time

The elite data from Roxlyfe.com tells a similar story:

| Component | Elite Men (~59 min) | Average Men (~90 min) |
|-----------|--------------------|-----------------------|
| **Running** | 30:46 (52%) | 42:26 (48%) |
| **Stations** | 25:10 (43%) | 39:50 (45%) |
| **Roxzone** | 2:54 (5%) | 6:58 (8%) |

**The takeaway is crystal clear:** Running is 50-60% of your race. Yet I see athletes spending 80% of their training time on station work. That's backwards.

Here's what the science says — VO2max is the **#1 predictor** of Hyrox finish time (correlation of -0.71). Body fat percentage is #2. Endurance training volume is #3. Strength metrics like grip strength and muscle mass? **Not statistically significant.**

Hyrox is fundamentally an **endurance event with strength components**, not the other way around. Your training split should reflect that — 40-50% aerobic/running work, with the remaining time on station-specific training prioritized by which stations have the highest time variance.

What's the Roxzone? My friend mentioned it but I don't really understand it.

The Roxzone is the **transition area** — the central zone inside the running track where all 8 workout stations are set up. Think of it this way:

- **Running track:** Loops around the outside perimeter of the venue (~1 km per lap)
- **Roxzone:** The big open area in the middle where you do SkiErg, sleds, burpees, rowing, farmers carry, lunges, and wall balls

After each 1 km run, you enter the Roxzone through a marked **IN arch**, jog to your next station, complete it, then exit through the **OUT arch** back onto the running track.

**Why it matters more than you think:** The Roxzone adds approximately **800 m to 1 km of extra movement** across the full race — just jogging between stations and the arches. And here's the kicker: elite athletes average about **20-25 seconds per transition** while recreational athletes average **52+ seconds**. Over 8 transitions, that's potentially **3+ minutes of free time** you're leaving on the table.

**Rules to know:**
- Enter through IN arch, exit through OUT arch — **2 min penalty** for using the wrong one
- **No outside assistance** in the Roxzone — no food/drink from friends or coaches (3 min penalty)
- Water is available at aid stations but **for drinking only** — pouring it on yourself is a 2 min penalty (new rule for 2025/26)
- Chalk is only allowed at sled pull and farmers carry — using it at other stations is a 2 min penalty

**Training tip:** Never treat transitions as rest. In training, practice jogging briskly between exercises. Set up your gym work so you're moving continuously between movements. Target under 45 seconds per transition if you're an intermediate athlete.

- Sled base weight is approximately **52 kg** — all listed weights include the sled

- Sandbags: **White = 10 kg, Grey = 20 kg, Black = 30 kg**

What rule changes do I need to know about for this season?

There are several important changes for the **2025/26 season**. Here are the ones that will actually affect your race:

**The big ones:**

1. **Women's Open Wall Balls: now 100 reps** (was 75). All divisions do 100 reps now. If you're a woman racing Open, this is a significant change — train for 100, not 75.

2. **Sandbag cannot be put down.** The sandbag must stay on both shoulders for the entire 100 m of lunges. First time you drop it = **15-second penalty** (no warning). Second drop = **DQ**. This is brutal. Train your sandbag lunges unbroken every single time.

3. **Active cooling is prohibited.** Water at aid stations is for **drinking only**. Pouring water on yourself = **2-minute penalty**. No more dumping cups over your head to cool down.

4. **Distance penalties removed for sleds, BBJ, and lunges.** Instead: 1 warning, then **15-second time penalty** per subsequent infringement. This means technique matters — short sled pushes or incomplete burpee jumps get penalized.

5. **Wrong wave start = automatic DQ.** No exceptions. Double-check your start time, arrive 10 minutes early.

**Other changes to be aware of:**
- Sled Pull: can't step on the front white line while holding the rope
- Burpee Broad Jumps: you're now allowed to use a knee when getting up from the bottom position
- Farmers Carry wrong weight: must **redo the entire station** or face DQ
- Chalk only allowed at sled pull and farmers carry (2 min penalty elsewhere)
- Spitting or clearing your nose on the floor: 2 min penalty

**Training implications:** The sandbag rule is the biggest game-changer. Build unbroken sandbag lunge capacity now. Start with 50 m unbroken at race weight, progress to 100 m. If you can't do 100 m unbroken in training, you're at serious risk of DQ on race day.

Tell me about Hyrox Doubles. My buddy and I want to race together.

Doubles is a blast. Here's what you need to know:

**Format:** Two-person team. Available as Men's Doubles, Women's Doubles, or Mixed Doubles (Open or Pro).

**The key differences from Singles:**

| Aspect | Singles | Doubles |
|--------|---------|--------|
| **Running** | Solo | **Both partners run together** for all 8 x 1 km |
| **Stations** | Individual | Partners **split the work** however you want |
| **Station distances** | Standard | **Doubled** for most stations |

**Doubled station distances:**
- SkiErg: **2,000 m** (split between partners)
- Sled Push: **8 x 12.5 m** (doubled)
- Sled Pull: **8 x 12.5 m** (doubled)
- Burpee Broad Jumps: **160 m** (split)
- Rowing: **2,000 m** (split)
- Farmers Carry: **400 m** (split)
- Sandbag Lunges: **200 m** (split)
- Wall Balls: **200 reps** (split)

**Critical rule:** Only **one partner works at a time** — the other waits. And you must **run together** — getting too far apart earns a 1 min penalty. Get 3 separation penalties and you're **DQ'd**.

**Strategy tip:** Split stations based on each partner's strengths. If your buddy is a monster on the SkiErg but struggles with wall balls, have him ski 1,200 m and you do 800 m, then you take 120 wall balls and he does 80. The optimal split is rarely 50/50 — it's about minimizing total time.

**For Mixed Doubles:** You race with **Men's Open weights** for all stations. Women use the 2.70 m wall ball target height. This is actually identical to Women's Pro weights, so make sure the female partner trains at that level.

What physiological demands should I expect during a Hyrox race?

Let me give you the actual data from the first peer-reviewed Hyrox study — Brandt et al. (2025), published in *Frontiers in Physiology*. They studied recreational athletes with a median finish of 86.5 minutes:

| Metric | Value | What It Means |
|--------|-------|---------------|
| **Max HR** | 185 bpm | Your heart will be near-max at multiple points |
| **Average HR** | 170.9 bpm | Sustained hard-to-very-hard intensity throughout |
| **Time above 90% HRmax** | **79.5%** of the race | You're in the red zone for nearly 80% of the event |
| **Time at 70-90% HRmax** | 19.6% | Only ~20% is merely "hard" |
| **Peak blood lactate** | 8.5 mmol/L | Peaks at wall balls — the final station |
| **Average blood lactate** | 6.3 mmol/L | Sustained moderate-high lactate throughout |
| **Max RPE (Borg scale)** | 18/20 | Near-maximal perceived effort at the end |

**Performance predictors (ranked):**
1. **VO2max** (r = -0.71) — aerobic capacity is king
2. **Body fat %** (r = 0.67) — leaner = faster
3. **Endurance training volume** (r = -0.68) — more endurance work = better
4. **Strength metrics** — hand grip strength, muscle mass = **NOT significant** (p > 0.05)

**What this tells us:** Hyrox is an aerobic endurance event disguised as a functional fitness competition. You'll spend nearly 80% of the race above 90% of your max heart rate. Blood lactate peaks at the final station because fatigue compounds.

**Training implication:** Build your aerobic engine first, station skills second. If you have a VO2max of 45 mL/kg/min, getting it to 52 will do more for your Hyrox time than adding 20 kg to your squat. The science is clear on this.

How is the running track set up at Hyrox? Is there a fast lane?

Yes — and knowing the course layout gives you a tactical edge. Here's how it works:

**Running Track:**
- Approximately 1 km loop laid out **around the perimeter** of the venue (outside edge)
- Depending on venue size, each 1 km run may be **1-5 laps** of the track
- A dividing line splits the track into two lanes:
  - **Fast Lane** (inside): For racers running at **4:00/km pace or faster**
  - **Running Lane** (outside): For everyone else

**Roxzone (Center):**
- All 8 stations are set up **inside** the running track, in the central area
- You enter/exit through marked **IN and OUT arches** along one side of the track
- The Roxzone adds approximately **800 m to 1 km** of extra jogging/walking distance across the full race

**Tactical considerations:**

1. **Don't use the Fast Lane unless you're actually running sub-4:00/km.** If you're in the Fast Lane running 5:30/km, you'll get in the way of faster athletes and potentially disrupt your own rhythm dodging people.

2. **The Roxzone distance is real and often overlooked.** You'll jog about 100-120 m per transition between the running track and your station. That adds up to nearly a full extra kilometer over the race. Factor this into your total race distance — you're really running closer to **9 km total**, not 8.

3. **Know your venue's lap count.** If your venue has 3 laps per 1 km run, you'll cross the IN arch 3 times before entering the Roxzone. Don't enter early. Count your laps.

4. **Start tunnel awareness:** You'll assemble in a designated start tunnel 10 minutes before your wave. Have your warm-up done and race plan reviewed before you get corralled.

What does the wave start system look like? When do I need to be there?

Here's how the wave system works:

**Wave basics:**
- Waves depart at regular intervals, typically **every 10 minutes**
- You're assigned a specific start time before race day, confirmed at check-in
- Your start time must be **written visibly on your arm**
- All racers in your wave are from the **same division** (e.g., all Men's Open together)
- Starting in the wrong wave = **automatic DQ** (this is new for 2025/26 and they're strict about it)

**Timing technology:**
- You wear a **timing chip on your ankle** that records splits for every segment
- It captures: each run time, each Roxzone entry/exit, each station completion
- This gives you detailed post-race data to analyze where you gained or lost time

**Wristband color coding:**
- **White** = Women's Open
- **Grey** = Women's Pro or Men's Open
- **Black** = Men's Pro
- **Green** = specific identifiers (varies)

**Your arrival timeline:**

| Time Before Wave | Action |
|-----------------|--------|
| **60-90 min before** | Arrive at venue, check in, scout the layout, locate bathrooms |
| **45 min before** | Start warm-up (see warm-up protocol) |
| **15 min before** | Finish warm-up, put on race shoes, final mental prep |
| **10 min before** | Assemble in **Start Zone Area** |
| **Wave start** | Go time |

Should I try to negative split my Hyrox runs? Or just go even pace?

**Even pacing is the gold standard for Hyrox.** The evidence is overwhelming.

Analysis from the 2022 HYROX World Championships showed that the **top 5 Elite finishers ran significantly more consistent splits** than the rest of the field. Those top performers had a **6-second or less difference** between their fastest and slowest 1 km run across runs 2-7. Meanwhile, the athletes with the slowest overall times tended to go out the *fastest* on Run 1.

Here's how the three strategies compare:

| Strategy | Best For | Risk | Efficiency |
|----------|---------|------|------------|
| **Negative Split** (start slow, finish fast) | First-timers, cautious athletes | Low | Good but leaves 1-3 min on table |
| **Even Pacing** (consistent effort) | **Most athletes** | Moderate | **Optimal** |
| **Fast Start** (bank time early) | Elite sub-1:15 athletes only | High | Fastest potential but highest blow-up risk |

**The data:** Athletes who pace evenly (within 10% variance across runs) finish **5-10% faster** than those who sprint early and fade late.

**The nuance:** "Even pacing" doesn't mean identical splits. You should expect runs 5-8 to be **10-20 seconds/km slower** than runs 1-2. That's physiologically normal from cumulative fatigue and cardiac drift. What you're aiming for is **consistent effort**, not identical pace. If your watch says 5:20 on Run 2 and 5:35 on Run 7 but both feel like the same effort level, you're nailing it.

**Specific run-by-run guidance:**
- **Run 1:** Start 5-10 sec/km **slower** than your target. The adrenaline will trick you.
- **Runs 2-4:** Settle into target pace. Resist speeding up because you "feel good."
- **Runs 5-7:** Allow a natural 10-15 sec/km drift. Don't panic.
- **Run 8:** Manage expectations — it often feels longer. Save a push for the final 200 m if you've paced well.

**My recommendation:** Negative splitting is fine for your first race as a safety strategy, but even pacing is what you should train for. Write your target pace on your wrist. Check every 500 m. Trust the plan, not the feeling.

What heart rate zones should I be in during the different parts of a Hyrox race?

Heart rate management is critical in Hyrox because you're constantly toggling between aerobic (running) and anaerobic (stations) for 60-150 minutes. One athlete completing Hyrox in 70 minutes had an **average HR of 154 bpm — 96% of max**. That's half-marathon intensity sustained across functional work.

Here's the zone guide:

| Race Phase | Target HR Zone | % Max HR | How It Feels |
|-----------|---------------|----------|-------------|
| **Runs 1-3** | Zone 3 (High Aerobic) | **70-78%** | Conversational to moderately hard |
| **Runs 4-6** | Zone 3-4 (Tempo/Threshold) | **75-85%** | Uncomfortable but controlled |
| **Runs 7-8** | Zone 4 (Threshold) | **80-88%** | Hard racing effort |
| **SkiErg / Rowing** | Zone 4 | **80-88%** | Controlled intensity, not max |
| **Sled Push/Pull** | Zone 4-5 | **85-92%** | Near-max leg effort, HR will spike |
| **Burpees / Lunges / Wall Balls** | Zone 4 | **80-90%** | Sustained muscular endurance |
| **Farmers Carry** | Zone 3-4 | **78-85%** | Grip/posture challenge > cardio |
| **Roxzone Transitions** | Zone 2-3 (Recovery) | **65-75%** | Active recovery — jog lightly |

**The #1 HR rule for Hyrox:**

**Do NOT exceed 85% of max HR during the first three runs.** This is the single most important pacing guideline. Going above this threshold early depletes glycogen disproportionately fast, spikes lactate, and accelerates core temperature rise — all of which compound exponentially in the second half.

Think of it as a **spending budget:** the aerobic energy you save in runs 1-3 by staying at 70-78% max HR is the exact energy you'll need for wall balls and runs 7-8.

**Cardiac drift warning:** By run 5-6, the same pace that kept you at 75% max HR in run 1 may produce 82-85% max HR. This is normal — core temperature rises, plasma volume decreases from sweating, glycogen depletes. Don't chase the same HR numbers in the second half. Shift to monitoring **perceived effort and pace** instead. If your pace is within 10-20 sec/km of early splits and you feel "controlled hard," you're on track.

**If HR exceeds 90-92% during runs in the second half:** Slow down immediately. Continuing at that intensity will cause a dramatic fade.

Should I stop and rest during the sled push or keep it moving?

**Keep it moving. Never let the sled fully stop.** This is physics, not opinion.

Here's the science: once the sled stops, **static friction** kicks in — and static friction is **3-5x greater** than kinetic (moving) friction. That means restarting a stopped sled costs enormously more energy than keeping it crawling. Even 1-2 inches per second of movement is better than zero.

At the 2023 HYROX North American Championships, many elite male competitors reportedly destroyed their entire race by going too fast on sled push. They gassed their quads and couldn't run properly for the rest of the event.

**Strategy by level:**

| Level | Strategy | Total Station Time |
|-------|---------|-------------------|
| **Beginner** | Stop-and-go with 3-5 sec rests (if you must) | ~5:00 |
| **Intermediate+** | **Continuous — never stop** | ~3:30 |
| **Elite** | Continuous, aggressive pace | ~2:30 |

**If you're intermediate or above:** Never let the sled fully stop. If you need to "rest," slow to a crawl but keep the sled inching forward. This maintains kinetic friction and avoids the massive energy cost of breaking static friction every restart.

**If you're a beginner and must stop:** Keep rests to **3-5 seconds maximum**. Stop approximately **5 steps before your legs start burning** — don't push until complete failure. Lactic acid clearance is exponential: the more you accumulate, the longer recovery takes.

**Technique essentials:**
- **Body angle:** Low — 45 degrees between torso and ground
- **Steps:** Short, choppy, **6-8 inch steps at 120+ steps per minute cadence**. Long strides create a stop-start pattern.
- **First 3 steps of each 12.5 m length:** MAX effort to break static friction
- **Breathing:** Exhale every 2-3 steps. Don't hold your breath.
- **Arms:** Extended for leverage or slightly bent — experiment in training

**Post-sled recovery protocol:**
1. Take 5 deep breaths with hands on knees at the end of the station
2. Shake out your quads before transitioning
3. Accept that Run 3 (immediately after sled push) will feel terrible — expect a 10-15 sec/km pace drop and don't panic

Going unbroken is killing your time, ironically. Here's what happens: you blast through 35-45 reps, your shoulders completely fry, and then you spend the last 55-65 reps in agony with 10-15 second breaks between sets of 5-8. | Strategy | Rep Pattern | Rest Between | Best For |
|----------|-----------|-------------|----------|
| Aggressive (Unbroken) | 100 straight | None | **Elite athletes only** — trained for it |
| Semi-Aggressive | 25-25-25-25 or 30-30-25-15 | 3-5 sec | Strong intermediate athletes |
| **Conservative (RECOMMENDED)** | **20-20-20-20-20** | **3-5 sec** | **Most athletes** |
| Very Conservative | 15-15-15-15-15-10-15 | 5-8 sec | Beginners or poor upper body endurance |

**Why 5 x 20 is optimal for most people:**

- 20 reps takes about 50-70 seconds — short enough that your shoulders don't reach failure
- 3-5 seconds of rest is just long enough for 2 deep breaths — you don't lose your rhythm or cool down
- The rest is so short you don't even set the ball down — hold it at chest height, breathe, go again
- **Math:** 5 x 20 with 4 sec rest = ~100 total reps in approximately 6:00-6:30. Compare that to going unbroken, failing at 40, then grinding out 60 more reps over 4-5 agonizing minutes = 7:30-9:00 total.

**Rep tempo:** Each wall ball should take **2.5-3.5 seconds** (catch → squat → drive → release → catch). Find a metronome-like rhythm and lock in. Consistent tempo is everything.

**Technique under fatigue:**
- Power comes from your **legs** (squat drive), not your shoulders
- Keep feet planted — shuffling wastes energy
- If the ball starts hitting below the target line, take a micro-break rather than accumulating no-reps from the judge
- Some venues now have digital targets that auto-count — no-reps won't register, so you'd repeat them without knowing

What's the deal with cardiac drift in Hyrox? My HR keeps climbing even when I slow down.

Cardiac drift is **inevitable** in Hyrox and understanding it will save you from making bad mid-race decisions.

**What's happening:** Over 60-150 minutes of sustained effort, three things occur simultaneously:
1. **Core temperature rises** — your body diverts blood to the skin for cooling, reducing blood available for muscles
2. **Plasma volume decreases** from sweating — less fluid means thicker blood, harder to pump
3. **Glycogen depletes** — your body shifts to less efficient fuel sources

Result: your heart must beat faster to deliver the same cardiac output. The same pace that kept you at 75% max HR in Run 1 may produce **82-85% max HR by Run 5-6**.

**How much drift to expect:**
- Moderate dehydration (1-2% bodyweight loss): HR increases **5-8 bpm** per 1% lost
- Over a 90-minute race, expect **8-15 bpm of upward drift** at the same effort level
- By Run 7-8, you may see HR readings 10-20% higher than Run 1 at the same pace

**How to manage it:**

1. **Don't chase the same HR numbers in the second half.** This is the critical mistake. If you try to stay at 75% max HR in the second half by slowing way down, you'll lose more time than the drift is worth.

2. **Shift to monitoring perceived effort and pace** after Run 4. If your pace is within **10-20 sec/km** of your early splits and you feel "controlled hard," you're on track — regardless of what your HR says.

3. **Red line alert:** If HR exceeds **90-92% of max for sustained periods** during runs in the second half, you NEED to slow down. Continuing at that intensity causes a dramatic, irrecoverable fade.

4. **Mitigate the drift with hydration:** Sip 100-200 ml at every water station. Every 1% bodyweight you don't lose from dehydration is 5-8 bpm of drift you prevent.

5. **Pre-race electrolyte loading helps:** 1500 mg sodium + 500 ml water 90 minutes before your wave. This expands plasma volume and delays the onset of drift.

**The practical takeaway:** Plan for runs 5-8 to be 10-20 sec/km slower than runs 1-3 at the same perceived effort. Budget this into your race plan. Don't panic when you see high HR numbers in the second half — that's physiology, not poor fitness.

1. Take **5 deep breaths** with hands on knees at the end of the station
2. **Shake out your quads** — 3-4 quick shakes per leg
3. Start moving toward the Roxzone exit. Don't stand still.

**The first 200 m of Run 3:**
- Accept that it will feel terrible. This is **expected, not a crisis.**
- Start at a **shuffle** — even 7:00/km pace is fine for the first 200 m
- Focus on getting your breathing rhythmic: 3 steps inhale, 2 steps exhale
- Let your HR settle from Zone 5 (sled push) back toward Zone 3-4
- Your legs will feel like concrete. After 200-300 m, the lactate begins to clear and running starts feeling more normal.

**Setup (maximize speed, minimize waste):**

- **Pull the rope through, don't gather it.** Let the rope pile beside you; don't try to coil it.

**Between lengths (this is where you win or lose):**
- Once the sled reaches you, **stand up quickly**
- **Run** (don't walk) back to the start position

I keep blowing up in the second half of Hyrox. My first 4 stations are great but then everything falls apart. What's happening?

This is the most common pattern in Hyrox — fast first half, death march second half. Here's exactly what's happening physiologically and strategically:

**The physiology:**
1. **Glycogen depletion:** You're burning through your primary fuel source too fast in the first half. By Station 5-6, you're running on fumes.
2. **Lactate accumulation:** High-intensity work at stations 1-4 drives blood lactate up. If you don't manage intensity, lactate stays elevated and compounds.
3. **Cardiac drift:** Your HR creeps up at the same pace/effort over time. By the second half, the same effort produces 10-15 bpm higher HR.
4. **Core temperature rise:** Indoor venues are hot. As your core temp rises, blood gets diverted to skin for cooling, leaving less for muscles.

**The strategic errors you're likely making:**

1. **Run 1 too fast.** You probably ran Run 1 at your standalone 5K pace or faster. Data shows the fastest finishers go out SLOWER on Run 1 than the athletes who eventually blow up.

2. **Sprinting the SkiErg and Row.** These stations have the lowest variance — blasting them gains you maybe 15-20 seconds but costs you enormously in glycogen and lactate.

3. **Over-pushing sled push.** The sled is where races are lost. Going too hard here destroys your quads for everything that follows — runs, lunges, wall balls.

4. **No mid-race fueling.** If you didn't take a gel by Station 4-5, you're glycogen-depleted by the second half.

**The fix — 5-point protocol:**

1. **Run 1 at target pace + 5-10 sec/km.** If targeting 5:15, run 5:25 on Run 1. It will feel easy. That's the point.

2. **Stay under 85% max HR for the first 3 runs.** Use your watch. If you're above 85%, slow down. This is non-negotiable.

3. **Conserve on SkiErg and Row.** 70-80% effort. Controlled. Save the intensity for wall balls and lunges where it actually pays off.

4. **Take a gel after Station 4 (BBJ).** 30g carbs. The boost kicks in 20-30 minutes later — right when you need it most.

5. **Accept 10-20 sec/km slower running in the second half.** Plan for it. Budget it into your race plan. Runs 6-8 being slightly slower than runs 1-4 is normal physiology, not failure.

**Reframe your race:** Think of the first half as an investment and the second half as the payoff. Every bit of energy you conserve in stations 1-4 is available for stations 5-8 where you need it most.

**Technique checklist:**
- Body angle: **45 degrees** — nose over toes, hips low
- Steps: **6-8 inches, 120+ steps per minute cadence**

- Breathe: exhale every 2-3 steps, don't hold your breath

**Fix 1: Get lower**

1. **Low fibre.** Switch to **white rice, white bread, white pasta, potatoes without skin** during the loading phase. Fibre slows digestion and causes bloating. Save the brown rice and whole grains for normal training days.

Here's why this matters:

At 88% max HR on Run 2, several things are happening:
1. **Glycogen burning rate is elevated** — you're using your most precious fuel source ~15-20% faster than necessary
2. **Lactate is accumulating** instead of clearing — above 85%, lactate production exceeds clearance rate
3. **Core temperature is rising faster** — higher HR = more metabolic heat = earlier onset of cardiac drift

**What likely happened in your race:**
- Run 2 at 88% → Stations 2-4 pushed you to 90%+ → By Run 5-6, you were at 90%+ even at a slower pace → Runs 7-8 were survival mode

**What SHOULD have happened:**
- Run 2 at 75-78% → Stations elevated to 80-85% → Roxzone dropped to 65-75% → By Run 5-6, cardiac drift brings you to 82-85% at the same pace → Runs 7-8 are hard but manageable

1. **Slow down runs 1-3 by 15-20 sec/km.** If you ran Run 2 at 5:00/km and hit 88%, try 5:15-5:20/km to stay at 78-80%.

2. **Use your HR monitor actively.** Set an alert for 85% max HR. If it beeps during runs 1-3, slow down immediately — even if it feels easy. The feeling of "I could go faster" is exactly right. That's energy in the bank.

3. **Hydrate better pre-race.** Dehydration accelerates cardiac drift. Every 1% bodyweight loss from sweat increases HR by 5-8 bpm. Preload with 1500 mg sodium + 500 ml water 90 minutes before your wave.

This is a textbook example of outcome-focused thinking destroying your race. You looked at the clock, compared your actual time to your goal time, felt the gap, panicked, and made irrational decisions. Let's rebuild your mental framework.

**What went wrong:** You were using an **outcome goal** ("I need to finish in X time") as your mid-race focus. When reality didn't match the goal, you experienced a stress response — elevated anxiety, loss of confidence, irrational pacing decisions. This cascaded through stations 6-8.

**The fix: Process goals over outcome goals.**

| Outcome Goal (BAD mid-race) | Process Goal (GOOD mid-race) |
|-----|-----|
| "I need to finish in 1:28" | "Hit 5:15 on this kilometer" |
| "I'm 3 minutes behind" | "Do 25 wall balls, then rest 4 seconds" |
| "I can't recover this time" | "Jog through this transition in 40 seconds" |

**Framework for your next race:**

1. **Before the race:** Set your outcome goal (1:28, whatever). Write segment-by-segment process goals on your wrist: run pace, station strategies, gel timing.

2. **During the race:** ONLY look at process goals. At the start of each segment, state the goal: "This run is 5:20." At the end, assess: "Did I hit it? What's the adjustment?" Move on. **Never carry frustration from one segment to the next.** Every segment is a fresh start.

3. **NEVER calculate your projected finish time mid-race.** This is the trap. If you're doing mental math at Station 6, you're not focused on executing Station 6.

- **"Get Out of the Chair"** — When 100 m of lunges or 100 wall balls feels overwhelming, don't think about the full distance. Just do the first rep. Then the next. Short-term focus keeps you present and moving.

- **"Embrace the Suck"** — The pain you felt at Station 6? Reframe it: "This pain is a signal I'm giving 5-10% more. It's not going to get worse. I just need to sustain this for a short period."

- **External focus** — Instead of "my legs hurt," think "I need to match that person's lunge tempo." Look at other athletes, count laps, engage with the crowd. External focus **reduces perceived effort** by up to 10%.

- **Station countdown** — After every station in the second half: "Farmers carry done. I will never carry again today. Only lunges and wall balls left." This shrinking-chunks technique creates momentum.

- **Mantras** — When complex thought breaks down under fatigue, use simple phrases:
  - "Smooth is fast"
  - "One more"
  - "I don't stop"
  - "This is what I trained for"

**Pre-race preparation:** Hide the total elapsed time display on your watch. Show only current lap/split pace. Remove the temptation to calculate. Trust the process goals, and the outcome takes care of itself.
